sen.j: 帰国後、訳詩編『於母影』、小説『舞姫』、翻訳『即興詩人』を発表し、また自ら文芸雑誌『しがらみ草紙』を創刊して文筆活動に入った。
sen.e: After coming back to Japan, he published a book of songs 'Omokage (Vestiges)', a novel 'Maihime (The Dansing Girl)' and a translated book 'Sokkyo Shijin (Improvising Poet)', and also began to issue a literary magazine 'Shigarami Soshi (Constraint Brochure)' by himself to start his career as a writer.

sen.j: 乃木希典の殉死に影響されて『興津弥五右衛門の遺書』発表後は、『阿部一族』『高瀬舟 (小説)』などの歴史小説、史伝『渋江抽斎』を書いた。
sen.e: After publishing 'The Last Testament of Okitsu Yagoemon' inspired by the incident that Maresuke NOGI followed his master to his grave, he wrote the historical novels such as 'The Abe Clan' and 'Takasebune (The Boat on the River Takase)' and a biography based on a historical evidence, 'Chusai SHIBUE'.

sen.j: なお、帝室博物館（現在の東京国立博物館、奈良国立博物館、京都国立博物館）総長や帝国美術院（現日本芸術院）初代院長なども歴任した。
sen.e: Besides, he successively assumed office as Director of Imperial Museum (Present Tokyo National Museum, Nara National Museum and Kyoto National Museum) and the first director of Imperial Art Academy (present The Japan Art Academy).

sen.j: 1862年2月17日（文久2年1月19日）、石見国津和野町(現島根県)で生まれた。
sen.e: He was born at Tsuwano-cho, Iwami Province (present Shimane Prefecture) on February 17, 1862.

sen.j: 代々津和野藩主、亀井公の御典医をつとめる森家では、祖父と父を婿養子として迎えているため、久々の跡継ぎ誕生であった。
sen.e: In the Mori Family which successively served as gotenni (doctor who is hired by bakufu) for KAMEI Lord of Tsuwano Domain, his grandfather and father were adopted as son-in-law, so it was a birth of a heir after a long time.

In the Mori Family who successively served as gotenni (doctor hired by the bakufu) for Lord KAMEI of Tsuwano Domain, his grandfather and father had both been adopted in the family as son-in-laws for lack of a male successor, so Ogai was the first heir born for a long time.
sen.cmt: KAMEI Lord>Lord KAMEI. 婿養子の部分については説明文を入れてみました。
sen.e: In the Mori family who successively served as goteni (doctor hired by the bakufu) for Lord KAMEI of Tsuwano Domain, his grandfather and father had both been adopted in the family as son-in-laws for lack of a male successor, so Ogai was the first heir born for a long time.

sen.j: また前年、祖父の白仙が東海道の土山宿で病死したため、とくに祖母は鴎外を白仙の生まれ変わりといって喜び、後年、鴎外が留学と出征から無事帰国するたびに、はらはらと涙を落としたという。
sen.e: Also, in the previous year, his grandfather, Hakusen, died of a disease at Tsuchiyama-juku Station of Tokaido, so his grandmoter was particularly delighted with Ogai's birth, looking at him as reincarnation of his grandfather, and later, whenever he safely came back to Japan from his study abroad or the front, she is said to have cried silently.

Also, as his grandfather Hakusen had died of disease the previous year at Tsuchiyama-juku Station on the Tokaido road, his grandmother was particularly delighted with Ogai's birth, looking at him as reincarnation of his grandfather, and it is said that later, whenever he safely came back to Japan from his study abroad or the front she would shed silent tears.

sen.j: 藩医の嫡男として、幼い頃から論語や孟子やオランダ語などを学び、藩校の養老館では四書五経を復読。
sen.e: As a heir of Edo-period doctor working at a public clinic, he learned Rongo Analects, The Book of Mencius, Dutch and so on from his childhood, and repeatedly read shishogokyo (the Four Books and Five Classics of Confucianism, the Nine Chinese Classics) at Yoro College, a hanko(domain school).

As the heir of a Han'i (doctor working at a public clinic), he had learned the Analects of Confucius, The Book of Mencius, Dutch and so on from childhood, and repeatedly read shishogokyo (the Four Books and Five Classics of Confucianism, the Nine Chinese Classics) at Yoro College, a hanko (domain school).

sen.e: As the heir of a Hani (doctor working at a public clinic), he had learned the Analects of Confucius, The Book of Mencius, Dutch and so on from childhood, and repeatedly read shishogokyo (the Four Books and Five Classics of Confucianism, the Nine Chinese Classics) at Yoro College, a hanko (domain school).

sen.j: 当時の記録から、9歳で15歳相当の学力と推測されており、激動の明治維新に家族と周囲から将来を期待されることになった。
sen.e: From the records of the times, his academic ability at 9 is presumed the same level as 15 years old, so his family and surroundings being in the upturn of Meiji Restoration put their hope in his future.

From records of the time, his academic ability at 9 was said to be the same level as a 15 year-old, so his family and those around him, amidst the upheaval of Meiji Restoration, put their hope in his future.

sen.j: 1872年（明治5年）、廃藩置県等をきっかけに10歳で父と上京し、翌年、住居などを売却して残る家族も故郷を離れた。
sen.e: In 1872, taking the opportunity of Haihan-chiken and so on, he went down to Tokyo along with his father at 10, and in the following year, the rest of his family also sold their residence and left their hometown to join them.

In 1872 at the age of 10, prompted by the abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures, he moved to Tokyo with his father, and the following year, the rest of his family also sold their residence and left their hometown to join them.

sen.j: 東京では、官立医学校（ドイツ人教官がドイツ語で講義）への入学に備え、ドイツ語を習得するため、1872年10月に私塾の進文学社に入った。
sen.e: He entered the Shinbungakusha school, a private school, in October 1872 in order to learn German preparing for the admission to Kanritsu Igakko (National Medical School) (where German instructors gave a lecture in German).

He entered the private Shinbungakusha school in October 1872 in order to learn German in preparation for admission to Kanritsu Igakko (National Medical School) where lectures were given in German by German instructors.

sen.j: その際に通学の便から、政府高官の親族西周 (啓蒙家)（にし・あまね）の邸宅に寄食した。

sen.e: Ogai who had such childhood was proficient in the foreign languages enough to defeat a German professor by bringing forward a counterargument in German.

sen.e: He used German and French a lot in his books and took citation from Chinese classics often.
He used German and French a lot in his books and often took quotes from Chinese classics.

sen.j: なお、西洋語学を習得する秘訣として、作品内で語源を学習に役立てる逸話を記した。
sen.e: Besides, as a key to learning western languages, he put an anecdote to use the origin of a word for learning in a book.
In addition, as a aid for those learning western languages, he added anecdotes to help memorize the derivation of words.

sen.j: 1873年（明治6年）11月、入校試問を受け、第一大学区医学校（現東京大学医学部）予科に実年齢より2歳多く偽り、11歳で入学。。
sen.e: He took the entrance exam and entered the preparatory school of Daiichi Daigaku-ku Igakko (present the University of Tokyo, Faculty of Medicine) in November 1873, at the age of 11, faking his age two years older than his real age (a fellow pupil, Moriharu MIURA, who later graduated at the top of the list, also entered in November).

sen.j: 1881年（明治14年）7月4日、19歳で本科を卒業（今後も破られないであろう最年少卒業記録）。
sen.e: On July 4 in 1881, he graduated from the regular course at 19 (this is the youngest record of graduation which would never be broken).
On July 4 1881, he graduated from the regular course at the age of just 19 (the youngest recorded age of graduation which has never been broken).

sen.j: 卒業席次が8番であり、大学に残って研究者になる道が閉ざされたものの、文部科学省派遣留学生としてドイツに行く希望を持ちながら、父の病院を手伝っていた。
sen.e: Although he missed the option to remain in the university to become a researcher because his class order at graduation was the 8th place, he held a hope to visit Germany as an oversea student under Ministry of Education, helping his father's clinic.

He did not have the chance to remain at the university to become a researcher as he only ranked 8th in his graduating class, but went on to help out his father's clinic, all the time dreaming of visiting Germany as an overseas student with the Ministry of Education,.

He did not have the chance to remain at the university to become a researcher as he only ranked 8th in his graduating class, but went on to help out his father's clinic, all the time dreaming of visiting Germany as an overseas student with the Ministry of Education.

sen.j: その進路未定の状況を見かねた同窓生の小池正直は、陸軍省医務局次長の石黒忠悳に鴎外を採用するよう長文の熱い推薦状を出しており、また小池と同じく陸軍軍医になっていた親友の賀古鶴所（かこ･つると）は、鴎外に陸軍省入りを勧めていた。
sen.e: A fellow pupil, Masanao KOIKE, who was anxious about him who couldn't move on to the next step, submit a long enthusiastique recommendation letter to Tadanori ISHIGURO, the vice-chief of Medical Bureau of Ministry of Army, requesting to employ Ogai, while his closest friend, Tsuruto KOGA, was encouraging him to join the Ministry of Army.

A fellow pupil, Masanao KOIKE, who was concerned about Ogai being unable to progress to the next step, submitted a long, enthusiastic recommendation letter to Tadanori ISHIGURO, the vice-chief of the Medical Bureau of the Department of War requesting him to employ Ogai, and his closest friend Tsuruto KOGA (who had become a Army Surgeon like Masanao) also encouraged him to join the Department of War.

A fellow pupil, Masanao KOIKE, who was concerned about Ogai being unable to progress to the next step, submitted a long, enthusiastic recommendation letter to Tadanori ISHIGURO, the vice-chief of the Medical Bureau of the Department of War requesting him to employ Ogai, and his closest friend Tsuruto KOGA (who had become a Army Surgeon like Masanao) also encouraged him to join the Department of War.

sen.j: 結局のところ鴎外は、同年12月16日に陸軍軍医副（中尉相当）になり、東京陸軍病院に勤務した。
sen.e: After all, Ogai was hired as Gunni-fuku of Army (corresponding to lieutenant) to work at Tokyo Army Hospital on December 16 of the year.
In the end, Ogai was hired as Gunni-fuku of Army (equivalent to lieutenant) to work at Tokyo Army Hospital from December 16 of that year.
In the end, Ogai was hired as Guni-fuku of Army (equivalent to lieutenant) to work at Tokyo Army Hospital from December 16 of that year.

sen.j: なお妹、小金井喜美子の回想によれば、若き日の鴎外は、四君子を描いたり、庭を写生したり、職場から帰宅後しばしば寄席に出かけたり（喜美子と一緒に出かけたとき、ある落語家の長唄を聴いて中座）したという。
sen.e: According to his younger sister, Kimiko KOGANEI's recollection, Ogai in his youth depicted Shikunshi (four plants with high virtue), sketched their courtyard and often went to yose (storyteller theater) after coming back from his work (she writes that he once took Kimiko, and intolerantly left before a Rakugo story teller finished his nagauta (long epic song with shamisen accompaniment).

According to the memoirs of his younger sister, Kimiko KOGANEI, Ogai in his youth made depictions of Shikunshi (four plants with high virtue), sketched their courtyard and often went to the yose (storyteller theater) after coming back from work; she writes that he once took her, but left halfway through before the Rakugo story teller finished his nagauta (long epic song with shamisen accompaniment).

According to the memoirs of his younger sister, Kimiko KOGANEI, Ogai in his youth made depictions of Shikunshi (four plants with high virtue), sketched their courtyard and often went to the yose (storyteller theater) after coming back from work; she writes that he once took her, but left halfway through before the Rakugo story teller finished his nagauta (long epic song with shamisen accompaniment).

sen.j: 入省して半年後の1882年（明治15年）5月、東京大学医学部卒の同期8名の中で最初の陸軍省医務局付となり、プロイセンの陸軍衛生制度に関する文献調査に従事し、早くも翌年3月には『医政全書稿本』全十二巻を役所に納めた。
sen.e: In 1882, half a year after his joining the Ministry, he was appointed to work at the medical bureau of Ministry of Army, for the first time for the eight graduates in the same class from the University of Tokyo, Faculty of Medicine, and engaged in the research of the literature on the Prussian army hygiene system, and handed over the total twelve volumes of 'Isei Zensho Kohon (Manuscript of Medical Science)' he had wrote to the public office as early as March of the following year.

In 1882, half a year after joining the Ministry, he was appointed among 8 graduates from the same class at the University of Tokyo to be the first to work at the medical bureau of Department of War, Faculty of Medicine, and engaged in research of literature on the Prussian army hygiene system, and as early as March of the following year submitted the entire twelve volumes of his work 'Isei Zensho Kohon (Manuscript of Medical Science)' to the public office.

In May 1882, half a year after joining the Ministry, he was appointed among 8 graduates from the same class at the University of Tokyo to be the first to work at the medical bureau of Department of War, Faculty of Medicine, and engaged in research of literature on the Prussian army hygiene system, and as early as March of the following year submitted the entire twelve volumes of his work "Isei Zensho Kohon" (Manuscript of Medical Science) to the public office.
sen.cmt: 記号を修正しました。日付補足しました。

sen.j: 1884年（明治17年）6月、衛生衛生学を修めるとともにドイツ陸軍の衛生制度を調べるため、ドイツ留学を命じられた。
sen.e: In June 1884, he completed the course of hygiene, and followed the order to go to Germany to look into the German Army's hygiene system.
In June 1884, he completed a course on hygiene, and followed an order to go to Germany to look into the German Army's hygiene system.

sen.j: 7月28日、明治天皇に拝謁し、賢所（かしこどころ）に参拝。
sen.e: On July 28, he was granted an audience with Meiji Emperor, and visited the Kashikodokoro (a palace sanctuary).
On July 28, he was granted an audience with the Meiji Emperor, and visited the Kashikodokoro (palace sanctuary).

sen.j: 8月24日、陸軍省派遣留学生として横浜港から出国し、10月7日にフランスのマルセイユ港に到着。
sen.e: On August 24, he left Yokohama Port as an oversea student under Ministry of Army, and arrived at Marseille Port in France on October 7.
On August 24, he left Yokohama Port as an overseas student under the Department of War and arrived at the Port of Marseille in France on October 7.
On August 24, he left Yokohama Port as an overseas student under the Department of War and arrived at the Port of Marseille in France on October 7.

sen.j: 同月11日に首都ベルリンに入った。
sen.e: Then he entered Berlin, the capital city of Germany, on 11 of the month.
He then entered Berlin, the capital of Germany, on the 11th of the same month.

sen.j: 最初の一年をすごしたライプツィヒ（1884年11月22日－翌年10月11日）で、生活に慣れていない鴎外を助けたのが、昼食と夜食をとっていたフォーゲル家の人達であった。
sen.e: In Leipzig where he spent the first year (from November 22, 1884 to October 11, 1885), Ogai who hadn't got used to his new life was supported by the Vogel Family who served him lunch and dinner.

sen.j: 次のベルリン（1887年4月16日－翌年7月5日）でも、早速北里柴三郎とともにロベルト・コッホに会いに行っており、細菌学の入門講座をへてコッホの衛生試験所に入った。
sen.e: In his next destination Berlin (April 16, 1887 - July 5, 1888), he went to see Robert Koch along with Shibasaburo KITASATO as soon as his arrival, then joined Koch's hygienic laboratory after completing a beginner's course of bacteriology.

sen.j: 肩書きの多いことに現れているように、鴎外は文芸活動の幅も広かった。
sen.e: As his many professions show, Ogai had a wide range of literary activities.

sen.j: たとえば、訳者としては、上記の訳詩集『於母影』（共訳）と、1892-1901年に断続的に発表された『即興詩人』とが初期の代表的な仕事である。
sen.e: For exemple, his initial representative works as a translator were 'Omokage (Vestiges)' (joint translation) mentioned above and 'Sokkyo Shijin (Improvising Poet)' intermittently published from 1892 to 1901.

sen.j: 『於母影』は明治詩壇に多大な影響を与えており、『即興詩人』は、流麗な雅文で明治期の文人を魅了し、その本を片手にイタリア各地をまわる文学青年（正宗白鳥など）が続出した。
sen.e: Omokage (Vestiges)' gave a great impact on the poet world of Meiji, while 'Sokkyo Shijin (Improvising Poet)' attracted men of literature in the Meiji Period with its flowing elegant sentences, so a lot of young literary enthusiasts (for exemple, Hakucho MASAMUNE) visited each region in Italy with the book in hand.

sen.j: また鴎外は、戯曲の翻訳も多く（弟の三木竹二が責任編集をつとめる雑誌『歌舞伎』に掲載されたものは少なくない）、歌劇（オペラ）の翻訳まで手がけていた。
sen.e: Ogai also translated a lot of plays (it's not few what were put in the magazine 'Kabuku' his younger brother edited as a responsible person), and even translated the opera.
Ogai also translated a lot of plays (of which a considerable number were put in the magazine 'Kabuku' which his younger brother was responsible for editing), and even translated opera too.

sen.j: ちなみに、訳語（和製漢語）の「交響楽、交響曲」をつくっており、6年間の欧米留学を終えた演奏家、幸田延（露伴の妹）と洋楽談義をした（「西楽と幸田氏と」）。
sen.e: He also created new Japanese words (Japanese Chinese words) such as 'Kokyogaku, Kokyokyoku (the both means symphony)', and had a discussion on the western music with Nobu KODA (a younger sister of Rohan), a player, who had come back to Japan after her six-year study in Enrope and America ('With western music, with MS. Koda).

He also created new Japanese words (based on Chinese characters) such as 'Kokyogaku, Kokyokyoku (both meaning symphony)', and gave a lecture on western music with Nobu KODA (a younger sister of Rohan), a musician who had come back to Japan after six-years' studying in Europe and America ('With western music and MS. Koda).

He also created new Japanese words (based on Chinese characters) such as 'Kokyogaku, Kokyokyoku' (both meaning symphony), and gave a lecture on western music with Nobu KODA (a younger sister of Rohan), a musician who had come back to Japan after six-years' studying in Europe and America ('With western music and Ms. Koda').

sen.j: そうした外国作品の翻訳だけでなく、帰国後から演劇への啓蒙的な評論も少なくない。
sen.e: Not only such translation of the foreign pieces, he also made not a few enlightenmental criticism on the play, after his back to Japan.
He not only translated such foreign pieces, he also made a good deal of philosophical critiques of plays after his return to Japan.
He not only translated such foreign pieces, he also made a good deal of philosophical critiques of plays after his return to Japan.

sen.j: 翻訳は、文学作品を超え、ハルトマン『審美学綱領』のような審美学（美学の旧称）も対象となった。
sen.e: The subject of his translation was not within the literature, and he also dealt with aesthetics such as 'Shinbigaku Koryo (aesthetic program)' of Hartmann.
The subject of his translations was not limited to literature; he also dealt with aesthetics such as 'Shinbigaku Koryo (aesthetic program)' by Hartmann.

sen.j: 単なる訳者にとどまらない鴎外の審美学は、坪内逍遥との没理想論争にも現れており、田山花袋にも影響を与えた。
sen.e: Ogai's aesthetics were more than a translator's one as shown in the dispute on "anti-idealism" with Shoyo TSUBOUCHI, and it also affected on Katai TAYAMA.
Ogai's study of aesthetics went further than that of a translator, as shown in the dispute on "anti-idealism" with Shoyo TSUBOUCHI, which also affected Katai TAYAMA.

sen.j: その鴎外は、上記のとおり東京美術学校（現東京藝術大学）の嘱託教員（美術解剖学・審美学・西洋美術史）をはじめ、慶應義塾大学の審美学講師、「初期文展」西洋画部門などの審査員、帝室博物館総長や日本芸術院初代院長などをつとめた。
sen.e: Beginning with a part-time professor (of artistic anatomy, aesthetics and western art history) of Tokyo School of Fine Arts (present Tokyo University of the Arts), Ogai also served as an istructor of aesthetics of Keio University, an examiner of the western painting department of 'the initial Bunten exhibition', the director general of Imperial Museum, the 1st director of The Japan Art Academy ans so on.

Starting as a part-time professor (of artistic anatomy, aesthetics and western art history) at Tokyo School of Fine Arts (present Tokyo University of the Arts), Ogai also served as an istructor of aesthetics at Keio University, an examiner of the western painting department of 'the 1st Bunten exhibition', the director general of Imperial Museum, the 1st director of The Japan Art Academy and so on.

Starting as a part-time professor (of artistic anatomy, aesthetics and western art history) at Tokyo School of Fine Arts (present Tokyo University of the Arts), Ogai also served as an instructor of aesthetics at Keio University, an examiner of the western painting department of 'the 1st Bunten exhibition,' the director general of Imperial Museum, the 1st director of The Japan Art Academy and so on.

sen.j: 交際も広く、その顔ぶれが多彩であった。
sen.e: He had a wide circle of acquaintances in every field.

sen.j: しかし、教師でもあった夏目漱石のように弟子を取ったり、文壇で党派を作ったりはしなかった。
sen.e: But, he didn't take apprentices or establish a new group in the literary world like Soseki NATSUME who was also a professor like him.

sen.j: ドイツに4年留学した鴎外は、閉鎖的で縛られたような人間関係を好まず、西洋風の社交的なサロンの雰囲気を好んでいたとされる。
sen.e: Ogai who had spent four years in Germany seemed to prefer the social atmosphere of salon in western style to the closed bound-like human relationship.
Ogai who had spent four years in Germany seemed to prefer the socialable atmosphere of Wester style lounges to closed, restricted human relationships.

sen.j: 高等官生活の合間も、書斎にこもらず、同人誌を主宰したり、自宅で歌会を開いたりして色々な人々と交際した。
sen.e: In spare moments from his work as a senior official, he edited a publication aimed at a particular hobby group or held a poetry reading at home to make a communication with different people.
In spare moments from his work as a senior official, he edited publications aimed at a particular hobby groups or held poetry readings at home to make contact with various different people.
In spare moments from his work as a senior official, he edited publications aimed at a particular hobby groups or held poetry readings at home to make contact with various different people.

sen.j: 文学者・文人に限っても、訳詩集『於母影』は5人による共訳であり、同人誌の『しがらみ草紙』と『めさまし草』にも多くの人が参加した。
sen.e: Even if limited to literary persons and men of letters, the Omokage (Vestiges), a translated book of poems, was translated by five persons, and 'Shigarami Soshi (Constraint Brochure)' and 'Mezamashi-gusa (Eye-awakening grasses) magazine', a publication aimed at a particular hobby group, were handled by a lot of people.

Even though it was limited to literary people and men of letters, the Omokage (Vestiges), a translated book of poems, was translated by five people, and 'Shigarami Soshi (Constraint Brochure)' and 'Mezamashi-gusa (Eye-awakening grasses) magazine', a publication aimed at a particular hobby group, were circulated to many people.

Even though it was limited to literary people and men of letters, the "Omokage" (Vestiges), a translated book of poems, was translated by five people, and "Shigarami Soshi" (Constraint Brochure) and "Mezamashi-gusa" (Eye-awakening grasses) magazine, a publication aimed at a particular hobby group, were circulated to many people.

sen.j: とりわけ、自宅（観潮楼）で定期的に開催された歌会が有名である。
sen.e: Especially, the poetry reading periodically took place at his home (Kanchoro House) is well known.
The poetry readings that periodically took place at his home (Kanchoro House) are especially well known.
The poetry readings that periodically took place at his home (Kanchoro House) are especially well known.

sen.j: その観潮楼歌会は、1907年（明治40年）3月、鴎外が与謝野鉄幹の「新詩社」系と正岡子規の系譜「根岸」派との歌壇内対立を見かね、両派の代表歌人をまねいて開かれた。
sen.e: The Poetry Reading at Kanchoro House took place in March 1907, from Ogai's concerns about the confrontation in the literary world, between Tekkan YOSANO's group following the line of 'Shinshisya (New Poetry Society)' and 'Negishi' School tracing the line back to Shiki MASAOKA, to invite the representative poet from each school.

The Poetry Readings at Kanchoro House began in March 1907, and as Ogai was concerned about causing confrontation in the literary world between Tekkan YOSANO's school, the 'Shinshisya (New Poetry Society)' and the 'Negishi' School which originated with Shiki MASAOKA, he invited a representative poet from each school.

The Poetry Readings at Kanchoro House began in March 1907, and as Ogai was concerned about causing confrontation in the literary world between Tekkan YOSANO's school, the 'Shinshisha' (New Poetry Society) and the 'Negishi' School which originated with Shiki MASAOKA, he invited a representative poet from each school.

sen.j: 以後、毎月第一土曜日に集まり、1910年（明治43年）4月までつづいた。
sen.e: After that, they began to get together on every first Saturday, and it continued until April 1910.
After that, they began to get together on every first Saturday of the month, and it continued until April 1910.
After that, they began to get together on every first Saturday of the month, and it continued until April 1910.

sen.j: 伊藤左千夫・平野万里・上田敏・佐佐木信綱等が参加し、「新詩社」系の北原白秋・吉井勇・石川啄木・木下杢太郎、「根岸」派の斉藤茂吉・古泉千樫等の新進歌人も参加した（与謝野晶子を含めて延べ22名）。
sen.e: Apart from Sachio ITO, Banri HIRANO, Bin UEDA, Nobutsuna SASAKI and others, the attendees were Hakushu KITAHARA, Isamu YOSHII, Takuboku ISHIKAWA and Mokutaro KINOSHITA from the group following the line of 'Shinshisya' and the new poets from 'Negishi' School such as Mokichi SAITO and Chikashi KOIZUMI (twenty-two people at total including Akiko YOSANO).

As well as Sachio ITO, Banri HIRANO, Bin UEDA, and Nobutsuna SASAKI, Hakushu KITAHARA, Isamu YOSHII, Takuboku ISHIKAWA and Mokutaro KINOSHITA from the 'Shinshisya' school and the new poets from 'Negishi' School such as Mokichi SAITO and Chikashi KOIZUMI also took park (twenty-two people in total including Akiko YOSANO).

sen.j: また、当時としては女性蔑視が少なく、樋口一葉をいち早く激賞しただけでなく、与謝野晶子と平塚らいてうも早くから高く評価した。
sen.e: Besides, the women were barely despised in this gathering contrary to the times, so Ichiyo HIGUCHI was soon found out as an excellent poet, and Akiko YOSANO and Raicho HIRATSUKA were also highly evaluated.

Also, as the group was relatively undiscriminatory against women for its time, Ichiyo HIGUCHI was soon discovered as an excellent poet, and Akiko YOSANO and Raicho HIRATSUKA were also highly evaluated.

Also, as the group was relatively undiscriminatory against women for its time, Ichiyo HIGUCHI was soon discovered as an excellent poet, and Akiko YOSANO and Raicho HIRATSUKA were also highly evaluated.

sen.j: 晶子（出産した双子の名付け親が鴎外）やらいてうや純芸術雑誌「番紅花」（さふらん）を主宰した尾竹一枝など、個性的で批判されがちな新しい女性達とも広く交際した。
sen.e: Ogai got along with the modern women with a strong individuality who tended to be criticized such as Akiko (whose twins were named by Ogai), Raicho, Kazue OTAKE who edited 'Saffron', a high art magazine, and so on.

Ogai got along with modern women who had a strong sense of individuality and thus were subject to criticism, for example Akiko (whose twins were named by Ogai), Raicho, Kazue OTAKE who edited high art magazine 'Saffron', and so on.

sen.j: その鴎外の作品には、女性を主人公にしたものが少なくなく、ヒロインの名を題名にしたものも複数ある（『安井夫人』、戯曲『静』、『花子』、翻訳戯曲『ノラ』（イプセン作『人形の家』））。
sen.e: Ogai produced not a few works which main character was female, and some of those had a title from the heroine's name ("Yasui fujin (The Wife of Yasui)", a play "Shizuka" and "Hanako", a translated play "Nora" (original title "A Doll's House" of Ibsen).

Ogai produced a fair number of works in which main character was female, and some of these had the heroine's name as a title, such as the plays "Yasui fujin (The Wife of Yasui)", "Shizuka" and "Hanako", plus the translated play "Nora" (original title "A Doll's House" by Ibsen).

Ogai produced a fair number of works in which main character was female, and some of these had the heroine's name as a title, such as the plays "Yasui fujin" (The Wife of Yasui), "Shizuka" and "Hanako," plus the translated play "Nora" (original title "A Doll's House" by Ibsen).

sen.j: 上記のとおり鴎外は、東京大学で近代西洋医学を学んだ陸軍軍医（第一期生）であり、医学先進国ドイツに4年間留学し、最終的に軍医総監（中将相当）・医務局長にまで上りつめた。
sen.e: As mentioned above, Ogai was an army surgeon (a member of the inaugural class) who learned the modern Western medicine at The University of Tokyo, then went to study in Germany, a medically advanced country, for four years, and finally moved on to the General Office Director of Army Surgeon (corresponding to Lieutenant General), Medical Office Director.

As mentioned above, Ogai was an army surgeon (a member of the inaugural class) who learned modern Western medicine at The University of Tokyo, then went to study for four years in medically advanced Germany, finally moving on to be General Office Director of Military Medicine (corresponding to Lieutenant General), and Medical Office Director.

As mentioned above, Ogai was an army surgeon (a member of the inaugural class) who learned modern Western medicine at The University of Tokyo, then went to study for four years in medically advanced Germany, finally moving on to be General Office Director of Military Medicine (corresponding to Lieutenant General), and Medical Office Director.

sen.j: 当時軍事衛生上の大きな問題であった脚気の原因について細菌による感染症との説を主張し、のちに海軍軍医総監になる高木兼寛（及びイギリス医学）と対立した。
sen.e: He insisted on his theory that beriberi which was a big concern in the military hygiene of the times was an infectious disease through germs, and was opposed to Kanehiro TAKAKI (and the British medical science) who later became the General Office Director of Navy Surgeon.

He asserted his theory that beriberi, a major concern in the military at the time, was an infectious disease spread through germs, in opposition to Kanehiro TAKAKI, who later became the General Office Director of Navy Surgeon, and British medical science.

He asserted his theory that beriberi, a major concern in the military at the time, was an infectious disease spread through germs, in opposition to Kanehiro TAKAKI, who later became the General Office Director of Navy Surgeon, and British medical science.

sen.j: 自説に固執し、当時海軍で採用していた脚気対策の治療法として行われていた麦飯を禁止する通達を出し、さらに日露戦争でも兵士に麦飯を支給するのを拒んだ（自ら短編「妄想」で触れている）。
sen.e: He was so obsessed by his theory that he issued an announcement to forbid eating barley rice which was taken as a diet for beriberi in the Navy of the times, and in the Russo-Japanese War also, he refused to supply barley rice to soldiers (as he mentioned in his short story 'Moso (Delusion)'.

He was so convinced of his theory that he issued an announcement to forbid eating barley rice which was taken as a diet supplement for beriberi in the Navy of the times, and in the Russo-Japanese War also, he refused to supply barley rice to soldiers (as he mentioned in his short story 'Moso (Delusion)'.

He was so convinced of his theory that he issued an announcement to forbid eating barley rice which was taken as a diet supplement for beriberi in the Navy of the times, and in the Russo-Japanese War also, he refused to supply barley rice to soldiers (as he mentioned in his short story 'Moso' (Delusion).

sen.j: 但し当時の医学水準上（ビタミンの未発見）麦飯食と脚気改善の相関関係は(ドイツ医学的には)科学的に立証されておらず、高木側は脚気の原因を(イギリス医学の手法である、患者と食料の統計学的分析から)蛋白質不足であるとしていた。
sen.e: However, the correlation between barley rice and the improvement of beriberi hadn't been scientifically proved (in the field of German medical science) because of the undeveloped medical standard of the times (vitamins hadn't been found yet), and Takagi considered the cause of beriberi as a short of protein (from the statistical analysis on the patients and foods).

However, because of the undeveloped medical standards of the time (vitamins were as yet unknown) the correlation between consuming barley rice and the improvement of beriberi had not been scientifically proven (in the field of German medical science), and Takagi considered the cause of beriberi to be a shortage of protein (from statistical analysis of patients and foods based on a british model).

However, because of the undeveloped medical standards of the time (vitamins were as yet unknown) the correlation between consuming barley rice and the improvement of beriberi had not been scientifically proven (in the field of German medical science), and Takagi considered the cause of beriberi to be a shortage of protein (from statistical analysis of patients and foods based on a British model).

sen.j: ともあれ結果的に陸軍は25万人の脚気患者を出し、3万名近い兵士を病死させる事態となった（同時期、海軍では脚気患者はわずか87名。
sen.e: In the consequence, the Army made 250 thousands beriberi patients, and near 30 thousands soldiers died from beriberi (meanwhile, the Navy had only 87 beriberi patients.
As a consequence, 250,000 people in the army suffered from beriberi, and nearly 30,000 soldiers died, however the Navy had only 87 beriberi patients.
As a consequence, 250,000 people in the army suffered from beriberi, and nearly 30,000 soldiers died, however the Navy had only 87 beriberi patients.

sen.j: 高木により食品と脚気の相関関係が予測され、兵員に麦飯が支給されたためである）。
sen.e: This was because Takagi anticipated the correlation between foods and beriberi, and supplied barley rice to soldiers.)
This was because Takagi anticipated the correlation between foods and beriberi, and supplied barley rice to soldiers.
This was because Takagi anticipated the correlation between foods and beriberi, and supplied barley rice to soldiers.

sen.j: 実に2個師団に相当する兵士が脚気で命を落とし、また戦闘力低下のために戦死した兵も少なくなく「（鴎外は）ロシアのどの将軍よりも多くの日本兵を殺した」との批判も存在している。
sen.e: The soldiers corresponding to the number of two divisions died from beriberi, and not a few soldiers were killed in the war because of losing their fighting energy due to beriberi, so Ogai was criticized that he had killed Japanese soldiers much more than any Russian general.

Two divisions' worth of soldiers died from beriberi, and many soldiers were killed in the war through lack of energy due to the disease, so Ogai was criticised for contributing more to the deaths of Japanese soldiers than any Russian general.

Two divisions' worth of soldiers died from beriberi, and many soldiers were killed in the war through lack of energy due to the disease, so Ogai was criticized for contributing more to the deaths of Japanese soldiers than any Russian general.

sen.j: 日露戦争終戦直前、業を煮やした陸軍大臣寺内正毅が鴎外の頭越しに麦飯の支給を決定、鴎外の面目は失われることとなった（寺内は日清戦争当時、具申した脚気対策に麦を送れと言う要望を鴎外により握り潰された経緯がある）。
sen.e: Just before the end of the Russo-Japanese War, Masatake TERAUCHI, a Minister of Army, got impatient and decided to supply barley rice ignoring Ogai attending there, thus, Ogai disgraced himself (Terauchi used to demand to send barley rice as a diet for beriberi during the Sino-Japanese War, but it was turned down by Ogai).

Just before the end of the Russo-Japanese War, Masatake TERAUCHI, the Minister of the Army, became impatient and decided to ignore the attendant Ogai and supply barley rice, making Ogai lose face (During the Sino-Japanese War Terauchi also demanded barley rice as a supplement for beriberi, but was turned down by Ogai).

Just before the end of the Russo-Japanese War, Masatake TERAUCHI, the Minister of the Army, became impatient and decided to ignore the attendant Ogai and supply barley rice, making Ogai lose face (During the Sino-Japanese War Terauchi also demanded barley rice as a supplement for beriberi, but was turned down by Ogai).

sen.j: 「予は陸軍内で孤立しつつあり」とは、この頃の鴎外の述懐である。
sen.e: Ogai later recalled, 'I was being isolated in the Army'.
Ogai later recalled, 'I was being isolated in the Army'.
Ogai later recalled, 'I was being isolated in the Army.'
sen.cmt: ピリオド位置移動しました。

sen.j: 後に鈴木梅太郎が脚気の特効薬であるオリザニン（＝ビタミンB1）を発見し、脚気との因果関係が証明されて治癒の報告が相次いだ。
sen.e: Umetaro SUZUKI later discovered オリザニン (=vitamin B1), a specific for beriberi, and the correlation with beriberi was proved, and the effect was reported one after anoter.
sen.cmt: webで検索しましたが、「オリザニン」のスペル不明です。
sen.e: Umetaro SUZUKI later discovered Oryzanin (Vitamin B1), a wonder drug for beriberi, and having proved its correlation with the disease, reports of its effectiveness were issued in quick succession.
Umetaro SUZUKI later discovered Oryzanin (Vitamin B1), a wonder drug for beriberi, and having proved its correlation with the disease, reports of its effectiveness were issued in quick succession.

sen.j: しかしその後も鴎外はかたくなに鈴木および学会の見解を批判した。

sen.e: From the point of view of the people who protect Ogai, people should consider the fact that, in the times, most of noncommissioned officers and soldiers (Japanese army) longed for eating polished rice after joining army, because barley rice was less tasty than polished rice (the rice polishing technology hadn't been developed yet compared to today), and also the history of beriberi.

sen.e: Kanehiro TAKAKI who had recommended eating barley rice proposed 'the theory on scattering the poor' to resolve the urban hygiene issue, and insisted on kicking the poor out of Tokyo.

sen.e: This insistence was certainly acceptable to some extent from the medical or public hygienic point of view, but there was a big problem of humanity, from which Ogai criticized the 'theory on scattering the poor' to the bottom, so they were deeply opposed each other even emotionally.

sen.e: Firstly, there is a fact that beriberi which ought to have 'exterminated' in the Navy surged again from the mid-Taisho Period (for exemple, even in Showa Period, the number of patients was 1,153 in 1928, and staying over 1,000 between 1937 and 1941).

sen.j: 兵食の問題（実は航海食がビタミン欠乏状態）、艦船の行動範囲拡大、高木の脚気原因説（たんぱく質と炭水化物の比例の失衡）の誤りの影響、「海軍の脚気は撲滅した」という信仰がくずれたこと（脚気診断の進歩もあって見過ごされていた患者を把握できるようになった（それ以前、神経疾患に混入していた可能性がある））である。
sen.e: The problem on the soldier food (the food on board was short of vitamins), the expansion of sailing area, the affect by Takagi's wrong theory on the causes of beriberi (unbalance between protein and carbohydrate), the collapse of the belief that 'beriberi in the Navy was exterminated' (thanks to the progress of the diagnosis standard of beriberi, the patients who might have been given another diagnosis could come to be diagnosed properly <before that, those patients might have been diagnosed as nervous disorder>).

sen.j: まず、陸軍の脚気惨害の責任について、戦時下で陸軍の衛生に関する総責任を負う大本営陸軍部の大本営組織（日清戦争日本軍の損害・石黒忠悳、日露戦争講和へ・小池正直）ではなく、隷下の一軍医部長を矢面に立たせることへの疑問である。
sen.e: First of all, the responsibility for the beriberi disaster should have been taken by the organization of Imperial headquarters in the Army Department because it was supposed to bear the whole responsibility for the Army hygiene during the war (Tadanori ISHIGURO, the damage to Japanese Army in the Sino-Japanese War, Masanao KOIKE, to the peace after Russo-Japanese War), but a director of the army surgeon department, a lower position than the above, was weirdly imposed the responsibility.

First of all, there is doubt surrounding the fact that responsibility for the beriberi disaster was not taken by the Army Department of the Imperial headquarters which was supposed to bear all responsibility for Army hygiene during the war (Tadanori ISHIGURO, in charge of Japanese Army casualties in the Sino-Japanese War, Masanao KOIKE, in charge of securing peace after the Russo-Japanese War), but by a director of the military medicine department, who was of a lower rank than them.

First of all, there is doubt surrounding the fact that responsibility for the beriberi disaster was not taken by the Army Department of the Imperial headquarters which was supposed to bear all responsibility for Army hygiene during the war (Tadanori ISHIGURO, in charge of Japanese Army casualties in the Sino-Japanese War, Masanao KOIKE, in charge of securing peace after the Russo-Japanese War), but by a director of the military medicine department, who was of a lower rank than them.

sen.j: 次に、鴎外が白米飯を擁護したことが陸軍の脚気惨害を助長したという批判については、日露戦争当時、麦飯派の寺内正毅が陸軍大臣であった（麦飯を主張する軍医部長がいた）にもかかわらず、大本営が「勅令」として指示した戦時兵食は、日清戦争と同じ白米飯（精白米6合）であった。
sen.e: Next, as for the criticism that Ogai worsened the beriberi disaster of the Army by insisting on the supply of polished rice, although the Minister of Army during the Russo-Japanese War was Masatake TERAUCHI who supported barley rice (he had a director of army surgeon department who insisted on the barley rice), the soldier food the Imperial headquarters instructed to supply by the 'Imperial edict' was the polished rice (polished rice 6 go) just like in the Sino-Japanese War.

sen.j: その理由として「麦は虫がつきやすい、変敗しやすい、味が悪い、輸送が困難などの反対論がつよく」、その上、脚気予防（理屈）とは別のもの（情）もあったとされる。
sen.e: Most of the opinions mentioned the negative effect of barley rice such as, 'the barley rice was easily infested with vermin or deteriorated, the taste was bad, the tranport was difficult', besides, there seemed to be another reason (emotional) apart from the prevention of beriberi (logical).

sen.j: 白米飯は庶民あこがれのご馳走であり、麦飯は貧民の食事として蔑まれていた世情を無視できず、また部隊長の多くも死地に行かせる兵士に白米を食べさせたいという心情があった。
sen.e: The polished rice used to be a big meal common people admired, while barley rice was despised as the food the poor ate, so such people's thoughts couldn't be ignored, besides, most of the troop leaders wanted the soldiers to eat the polished rice before leaving for the front where they might be killed.

Polished rice used to be considered a feast common people dreamed of, while barley rice was looked down on as the food of the poor, and such thoughts could not be ignored, besides, most troop leaders wanted to give their soldiers the treat of polished rice before leaving for the front where they might be killed.

sen.j: 最後に、鴎外の「陸軍兵食試験」が脚気発生を助長したという批判については、兵食試験の内容（当時として正しい試験で正しい結論）を把握せず、しかもビタミンの存在を知っている後世から、その存在を知らなかった前世への暴論である。
sen.e: Finally, as for the criticism that Ogai's 'examination on the Army solders' food' prompted beriberi to occur, the people in the later generation even don't know the contents of the examination on the soldier food (it was a right test and a right conclusion at the time), and it was nothing but a wild view of the later generation who knows what the vitamins are, imposed to the earlier generation who had no idea on the vitamins.

Finally, as for the criticism that Ogai's 'examination of soldiers' food' prompted beriberi to occur, it is simply an irrational argument imposed by later generations with the knowledge of vitamins, on an earlier generation whose methods and conclusions were suitable and correct for the knowledge that existed at the time.

As we have seen, some say most of the criticism towards Ogai on the beriberi issue is misdirected.

sen.j: 鴎外への批判が起こった理由として、海軍の兵食改良を批判しすぎたこと、論理にこだわりすぎて学術的権威に依拠しすぎたこと、日清戦争時の上官の石黒に同調したことが挙げられる。
sen.e: The reasons why Ogai had to be criticized are that he criticized the Navy's soldier food reform too much, insisted on the logic and relied on the academic authorities too much, sympathized with Ishiguro, his superior officer in the Sino-Japanese War, and so on.

The reasons Ogai was targeted include the fact he overly criticised the Navy's soldier food reform, relied on logic and the academic authorities too much and sympathized with Ishiguro, his superior officer in the Sino-Japanese War.

The reasons Ogai was targeted include the fact he overly criticized the Navy's soldier food reform, relied on logic and the academic authorities too much and sympathized with Ishiguro, his superior officer in the Sino-Japanese War.

sen.j: なお、脚気問題で批判される根拠としては、日露戦争後に鴎外がトップの陸軍省医務局長になったとき、麦飯を禁止して違反者を取り締まった事実や「脚気減少は果して麦を以て米に代へたるに因する乎」という論説を衛生関連の7雑誌に掲載したことで牽制する結果を招いた事（『鴎外全集』第34巻、165-168頁）、｢勝てば官軍」等に表されるように軍人は特に経過を問われずに結果だけで評価されやすい事などがあげられる。
sen.e: Besides, the reasons why he was criticized on the beriberi issue are that he punished the people who violated the ban of barley rice when he became the Director of the Medical Office in the Ministry of Army, that he put his theory about 'whether decrease of beriberi could be brought by barley rice instead of polished rice' in the seven magazines related to hygiene, which led to restraining his counterparty ('MORI Ogai Zenshu (the Complete Works of Ogai MORI)', Vol. 34, page 165 to 168), that the military men particularly tended to be evaluated only by the results regardless of the story behind as' shown in the phrase 'If win, it's Imperial army', and so on.

Furthermore, the reasons he was criticized on the beriberi issue are that he punished those who violated the ban of barley rice when he became the Director of the Medical Office in the Ministry of War, that he published his opinion on 'Can a decrease in beriberi be brought about by using barley rice instead of polished rice' in seven magazines related to hygiene, thus leaving no room for his competitors ('MORI Ogai Zenshu (the Complete Works of Ogai MORI)', Vol. 34, page 165 to 168), and that military men tended to be evaluated only on results, regardless of circumstances, as shown in the phrase 'Winning is what makes the Imperial army'.

Furthermore, the reasons he was criticized on the beriberi issue are that he punished those who violated the ban of barley rice when he became the Director of the Medical Office in the Ministry of War, that he published his opinion on 'Can a decrease in beriberi be brought about by using barley rice instead of polished rice' in seven magazines related to hygiene, thus leaving no room for his competitors ('MORI Ogai Zenshu (the Complete Works of Ogai MORI),' Vol. 34, page 165 to 168), and that military men tended to be evaluated only on results, regardless of circumstances, as shown in the phrase 'Winning is what makes the Imperial army.'

sen.j: 常日頃、文人の自分と武人のそれを厳格に分けて考えていた。

sen.j: あるとき文壇の親しい友人が軍服を着て停車場にいた森に何気なく話しかけたら、その友人を怒鳴りつけたことがある。
sen.e: One day, a familiar friend from the literary world unconsciously talked to Mori who was standing at a stop in military uniform, then he got upset and shouted at the friend.
Once, when Mori was standing at a station wearing military uniform, a close friend from the literary world casually started talking to him, making Mori get upset and shout at him.
Once, when Mori was standing at a station wearing military uniform, a close friend from the literary world casually started talking to him, making Mori get upset and shout at him.

sen.j: 軍人としての誇りが高く、娘と散歩する時にも必ず軍服に着替えた。
sen.e: He was so proud of being a military man that he put on his uniform whenever he took a walk with his daughter.
He was so proud of being a military man that he put on his uniform whenever he took a walk with his daughter.
He was so proud of being a military man that he put on his uniform whenever he took a walk with his daughter.

sen.j: あるとき杏奴と散歩をしていると、「わー中将が歩いているぞ」と子供たちがバラバラと駆け寄ってきた。
sen.e: One day, when he was taking a walk with Annu, children ran to them, shouting 'Here comes a lieutenant general'.
One day, when he was taking a walk with Annu, children ran up to them, shouting 'Here comes a lieutenant general'.
One day, when he was taking a walk with Annu, children ran up to them, shouting 'Here comes a lieutenant general.'
sen.cmt: ピリオド位置移動しました。

sen.j: 日露戦争後で、軍人が子供たちのヒーローであったのである。
sen.e: The Russo-Japanese War had just been over, so a military man was children's hero.
The Russo-Japanese War had just ended, so military men were children's heros.
The Russo-Japanese War had just ended, so military men were children's heroes.

sen.j: 得意満面の鴎外を、あこがれの目で見つめていた子供たちの一人が、襟の深緑色を見て、「おい、なんだ、軍医だよ」と声をあげると、「なーんだ、軍医かあ」と言いながら子供たちは散ってしまった。
sen.e: But, one of the children staring Ogai's face in full of satisfaction noticed his dark green badge on the collar and shouted, 'Oh, no, he is an army surgeon.', then the other children shouted 'Oh, boy, he's just an army surgeon.', and ran away.

But, one of the children, seeing Ogai's self-satisfied expression, noticed the dark green badge on hus collar and shouted, 'What's that? He's just an army surgeon,' then the other children shouted 'Ooh, he's just an army surgeon.', and ran away.

But, one of the children, seeing Ogai's self-satisfied expression, noticed the dark green badge on his collar and shouted, 'What's that? He's just an army surgeon,' then the other children shouted 'Ooh, he's just an army surgeon,' and ran away.
sen.cmt: スペル修正しました。記号を修正しました。

sen.j: あとには呆然として立ち尽くす父娘が残され、がっかりとした鴎外は帰宅するまで、一言もしゃべらなかったという。
sen.e: Stunned, the father and daughter were left behind alone, and Ogai, so disappointed, is told to not have said even a word on the way home.
Stunned, the father and daughter were left alone, and it is said Ogai was so upset he didn't say a word on the way home.
Stunned, the father and daughter were left alone, and it is said Ogai was so upset he didn't say a word on the way home.

sen.j: 1892年に東京都文京区へ建設し、晩年まで過ごした住居「観潮楼」跡地に、文京区立本郷図書館鴎外記念室がある。
sen.e: On the site in Bunkyo-ku Ward where "Kanchoro House", a residence which Ogai built in 1892 and lived in until his later years, used to be, there is now the Ogai Memorial Hall in Hongo Public Library belonging to Bunkyo-ku Ward.
sen.cmt: web上の記載を参照したところ、「本郷図書館鴎外記念室」という文言が抜けていましたので、オリジナルに挿入し、英訳してあります。
sen.e: On the old site of "Kanchoro House" in Bunkyo-ku Ward, a residence which Ogai built in 1892 and lived in until his later years, there now stands the Ogai Memorial Hall and Hongo Public Library.
On the old site of 'Kanchoro House' in Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo, a residence which Ogai built in 1892 and lived in until his later years, there now stands the Ogai Memorial Hall and Hongo Public Library.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ補足しました。記号を修正しました。用語統一しました。

sen.j: 細菌学を究めて以来、ルイ・パスツール同様潔癖症になってしまい、どんな食べ物も加熱しないと食べられなくなってしまったという。
sen.e: After he had mastered the bacteriology, Ogai was obsessed with being clean just like Louis PASTEUR, and he came to be unable to eat anything not heated.
Having mastered bacteriology, Ogai was obsessed with being clean just like Louis PASTEUR, and he came to be unable to eat anything not cooked.
Having mastered bacteriology, Ogai was obsessed with being clean just like Louis PASTEUR, and he came to be unable to eat anything not cooked.

sen.j: その一方で、風呂嫌いでもあった。
sen.e: On the other hand, he hated taking a bath.
On the other hand, he hated bathing.
On the other hand, he hated bathing.

sen.j: 大の甘党でもあり、娘（茉莉・杏奴）の著書によると饅頭を茶漬けにして食べていたという。
sen.e: He had a sweet tooth, and according to his daughters' (Mari and Annu) books, he ate Manju (a bun stuffed with azuki-bean paste) soaked in Japanese tea.
He had a sweet tooth, and according to the books of his daughters Mari and Annu, he used to eat Manju (a bun stuffed with azuki-bean paste) soaked in Japanese tea.
He had a sweet tooth, and according to the books of his daughters Mari and Annu, he used to eat Manju (a bun stuffed with azuki-bean paste) soaked in Japanese tea.

sen.j: これは潔癖症も原因で、食品を砂糖漬けにしたり、熱湯をかけたりすれば細菌は死滅するから、という考えもあったようだ。
sen.e: His obsession with being clean made a part of the reason, and he seemed to consider any preserved food in sugar or food soaked in boiled water would be safe because germs died out.
Part of the reason for this was his obsession with cleanliness, and he is said to have considered any food preserved in sugar or soaked in boiling water to be safe because germs would be killed off.
